Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2017 02:48PM beahm3 wrote: Well- I called my primary care doc this morning to see if biopsy results were in. Receptionist said yes, results benign follow up with ultrasound in 2 months. Im in a daze. I have, like many of you been anxious about this for a few months now and the only positive information I have gotten online is right here on this forum. Thank you for that. I will be changing primary care docs for several reasons, one of which she is not very reliable when it comes to advice. I don't know when she would have gotten back to me with the results so I called, went in and got my own copy. djmammo-if you don't mind I still have a couple questions? I have 2 pages of information in front of me and no where on either of them do I see the word "benign" or "malignant". I do see: "No monotypic B cell population, phenotypically abnormal t cell population or blast cell population detected". Blasts: Not increased by CD45/side scatter. B-cells: No monotypic; normal expression pattern of CD19, CD20, CD5, CD-10, CD23, surface kappa and lambda. T-cells/NK cells: No aberrant phenotype by CD3, CD5, CD7, and CD10. Viability: Acceptable Viable Lymphocytes (7-AAD): 98% I will be going over this with my doctor. And I appreciate your help.

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2017 10:00PM beahm3 wrote: Sorry...just ONE more question. I really am NOT trying to borrow trouble here...just trying to be my own advocate. After getting the benign results from my core biopsy in June, having the follow up ultrasound last week and the lymph node not changing in size (still big) ...I'm wondering if it is commonplace for follow up biopsies to be performed if a lymph node just decides to stay inflamed? Also, here comes the borrowing trouble part, I guess it's possible that the core biopsy missed something? The axillary lymph node that is inflamed is pretty obvious not at all hard to get to and if I remember correctly, four to six samples were taken. Funny, if it wasn't achy I wouldn't give it a second thought but it keeps reminding me that it's there. :-( Also, I am avoiding getting the Tdap vaccine with a new baby arriving soon in the family for fear the vaccine may affect the lymph node? Sorry again...that was more than one question.
Posts.Title: 3.5cm lymph node found by US in axillary area beahm3 beahm3

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2017 10:00AM beahm3 wrote: Hi all- just returned from getting the biopsy. All of your input is so spot on with this process. And again, thanks for that! First of all it was explained to me that they very rarely do the FNS's unless it is of the thyroid....instead, djmammo, they opt for the core biopsy. Made perfect sense. I really didn't see the point of FNA if there was such a big chance of being called back. For me, at least, this was a very easy procedure. No pain at all. Took about 20 mins. Even the numbing of the area was quick and less "pinchy" than novacaine at the dentist. The doctor took 4 samples and I was able to watch the screen while the nurse was doing the ultrasound. All in all a relatively smooth experience. I did gather my courage to ask him what he thought....letting him know that I know he can't tell much yet. He agreed with that and since I wont know anything until early next week, he said that if he had to guess, he would guess that it is simply an enlarged lymph nope and I THINK he may even have said nothing to worry about. I may have imagined that, tho. hahaha. One more thing. This lymph node was measured previously, about a month ago at 3.5 cm....today it was measured at a "little under 3cm". Not sure if that means anything or not. May have even been an incorrect first measurement. So- that's that. Thank you again for your support and wisdom. I will keep you posted. Just wanted anyone who is concerned about pain with a core biopsy, please don't worry. The anticipation is way worse than the procedure. For me, I wouldn't even say I was uncomfortable...just nervous.

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2017 01:43PM beahm3 wrote: Just returned from my 2 month follow-up ultrasound on my enlarged axillary lymph node. Djmammo- the report does mention, like you said, they would be looking for fluid collection, etc. You also mentioned that you didn't expect a change in size of the lymph node. What has me concerned is that there is a slight increase in size but they do mention that the node is, "still well defined and wider than tall" I noticed on the report that the size has gone from 3.5x1.1x2.2 cm to 3.8x1.1x2.6. That kind of concerns me altho the size of the node does seem to fluctuate. My question is, even tho the biopsy was negative could having an enlarged node like this eventually lead to a problem in the breast? And would removal possibly prevent any future problems? The slight size increase was not a concern apparently, since the report says, "This does not appear to be changed". Thanks so much for any insight!

Wouldn't a blood test reveal if there was any type of infection? You would think that that would be one of the first steps? Also, a question I have about a term used on the US report: "Normal fatty hilum displaced"...that sounds like a bad thing. Posts.Title: 3.5cm lymph node found by US in axillary area beahm3 beahm3

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2017 01:54PM beahm3 wrote: Thanks for your reply, Djmammo. The shingles were mostly center of back down low...but, random around the lower and upper back. I know that typically they are one sided...but, have read that isn't always the case? I didn't realize that that is probably what I had. After a few days of headache, fever and overall ickyness is when the rash began and lasted for a couple weeks. Do not have a cat. Was around my daughters cat a month or so ago...but, no scratching...it was just near me. I'm more of a dog person. :-) I do work outside gardening alot and also do some woodworking so, I often have scratches and bumps. Also, get splinters once in a while. I'm assuming this one lymph node is the only one swollen and originally I went to my GP just to see why there was puffiness up in front of the armpit over the muscle. Never did feel anything there....just that it's a little puffy. Thats when she said not to worry about it and it looked/felt like an "inflamed tendon" (after planting 30 trees). I have noticed this puffiness before over the past 5 years but then it kind of goes away. But, the area is always a little larger on the right side compared to left. Maybe cuz I'm right handed. So, was hoping maybe its just a worn out lymph node that just wants to stay large. I don't have symptoms of a problem anywhere else. Also, just as a kind of interesting point...I have had Lyme disease with bulls-eye rash twice in the past 7 years and took a months worth of antibiotic each time. Maybe if thickening of cortex was not mentioned it was not an issue when he looked at the pictures? I would think if it helped explain the condition of the node he would have included it in report. sheesh. I would have thought if he rated it a birad 3 he must have leaned one way or the other? Why not do birad 4 if there had been cortical thickening? Who knows. Thanks so much for your knowledge and help.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2017 02:45PM beahm3 wrote: Hi- Just picked up both mammo and US test results. And I'm still lost. Ultrasound: "In right axilla there is a solitary prominant node measuring 3.5x1.1x2.2cm. The normal fatty hilum is displaced. This could indicate pathology such as inflammatory node although malignancy cannot be excluded." No masses found and compared to last mammo everything is the same. "This could be biopsied under ultrasound guidance. BI-Rads #3 probable benign findings".He also mentions a subtle area of ill defined shadowing in upper outer aspect of right breast without a corresponding mass. . I think I have always had that and it shows on all previous mammos and doesnt change. I remember being called back for that in the early 1990's. Shadowing with no mass. Just dense tissue? 3D Mammo came back BI-RADS 1 negative. Also...I just keep wondering if this could be the result of a case of Shingles I had about 8 weeks ago. Could it just be a really sensitive lymph node? Seems to feel better if I put heat on it for a short time. It's just a little achy now since it was pushed during US. Thanks...I know I can't be diagnosed online :-) and I do have an appt set up with surgeon tomorrow...will get a second opinion from him also. Just wish I could calm my nerves somehow.

Posts.Content: beahm3 wrote: Hi. I'm panicked. I am a 64 yo pretty healthy woman.So thankful to have others to talk to about this. About a month and a half ago I noticed a slight, soft puffiness in the front of my right armpit...noticed only when arm is about head. No lumpiness and the puffiness is soft. I have noticed this in the past but it wasnt as pronounced. Figured it was from all the heavy lifting and gardening I do. Had a mammo about 6 weeks ago. Came back fine. But, went to my GP to check out fullness under arm. She said it looked like an inflamed tendon...but knowing how much I worry she said I could go get an ultrasound. Got ultrasound. Radiologist did not say much except possible swollen lymph node...3.5cm. He recommended needle biopsy and follow up in 6 months. My GP saw results and recommended seeing a surgeon and have the lymph node removed. So, I have an appt for a consult in 2 days. No pain, just a little achiness especially after the poking and prodding of US. So, now, with many of you...I wait. Makes me wonder tho why radiologist and GP are so far apart with their recommendations? Thanks so much for any ideas or if any of you have been thru this type of thing? Also, I did have a "mild" case of Shingles about a month and a half ago...but, docs seem to dismiss that as cause of swollen gland. Thanks again for any ideas. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 3.5cm lymph node found by US in axillary area beahm3 beahm3

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2017 09:41PM beahm3 wrote: It has been about a month since my core biopsy and will be following up with my doctor and making appt for another ultrasound at the end of August. In this past month I have come up with a list of questions to ask my doctor but since I won't be seeing her for a few weeks I thought maybe I could get a few answered here! djmammo- I was wondering exactly what a biopsy of enlarged axillary lymph nodes typically looks for. Is it usually checking only for Lymphoma or could you tell by the info I posted if the core biopsy I had also checked for any infections or other cancers which may be causing the enlarged lymph node? Also, and I know I am borrowing trouble here...but, is it possible for the wrong lymph node to be biopsied? It didn't seem like the technician or the doctor had reviewed my case beforehand. I had to explain why I was there...maybe that is standard operating procedure? So, basically what I am wondering is exactly what this biopsy ruled out...and did it get to the bottom of anything or should I be prepared for more testing. Having an enlarged "benign" lymph node is something that wouldn't bother me but I'm just wondering if all the bad stuff has been ruled out. After hearing that the results were benign I thought I had put it behind me at least until the next ultrasound but over the last couple weeks it seems like new symptoms have popped up. There seems to be more achiness at the top outer side of my breast on the side where the biopsy was done. Maybe I am just focused on it too much. :-/ Anyway, thanks for any help you can give me!
